column1: Blood flow is slow from the veins in your legs back to your heart.
As a result, you may have: - Varicose veins - Swelling in your legs - Skin changes or even a skin ulcer (sore) in your lower legs These problems usually get worse over time.
Learn self-care that you can do at home to: - Slow down the development of varicose veins - Decrease any discomfort - Prevent skin ulcers
When you do sit or stand, bend and straighten your legs every few minutes to keep the blood in your legs moving back to your heart.

Call for an appointment with your health care provider if: - Varicose veins are painful - Varicose veins are getting worse - Putting your legs up or not standing for a long time is not helping - You have a fever or redness in your leg - You have a sudden increase in pain or swelling - You get leg sores
